title: Ford Built Wild & Built to Electrify
subtitle: lorem ipsum
body:
When autoshows returned after Covid during the summer of 2021, Ford wanted to make a big impression for its flashiest cars - the Bronco and the Mach-E.

TThe Bronco draws customers in because of its off-roading capabilities and Ford wanted to demonstrate just that. Imagination designed and built an obstacle course ending with “The Mountain” to showcase the Bronco’s peak incline and decline angles.

The Mach-E is Ford’s electric sports car with an impressive ability to accelerate from 0-60 in 3.5 seconds. With this same desire to show off peak performance, Ford had a runway for drivers to put the pedal to the metal and allow participants to feel the speed for themselves.

In both cases, Ford wanted customers to have a digital souvenir to go home with to remember these experiences. So as part of the activation, we built an application that records visitors’ reaction at the exact moment of surprise and delight and programmatically edit the video for a keepsake they could view and share afterwards.
skills: Python, Angular, Scss, Node.js, Next.js, RabbitMQ, MySql

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body:
The goal of the project was get clips of video on peak incline/decline for the Bronco and peak acceleration for the Mach-E.

In order to do this, we had an accelerometer and gyroscope in the trunk of each vehicle. We used a python script on a raspberry pi to read and process these numbers continuously. We used the accelerometer readings directly for the Mach-E, but the Bronco needed data on the incline angle of the car, so we used the data from both sensors and the complimentary filter to combine them into an incline angle.

All of this data was then sent to the video recording application running on a laptop, also in stored in the trunk of the car. The application was connected to a webcam attached to the dashboard that recorded the participants in the back seat. As the vehicle hit incline, decline, and acceleration thresholds, the video application recorded timestamps. Once the ride ended, the video and timestamps were then passed off to the video processing application.

The backend which received these requests and did the video processing was run on a physical server kept in back of house. The video processing application itself was run in a docker container on a virtual machine on that server. The application used a node backend to queue jobs using rabbitmq as they came in from the frontend and a node worker to process each job. Ffmpeg was used to splice the video at the given timestamps, add clips of stock video, audio, and a layover. It then sent the final product to Amazon S3 for storage and an email to the user for them to view and share.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.body: The "Built Wild" and "Build to Electrify" activations debuted at the Chicago Autoshow 2021 with massive success. Ford continued with the program for the 2021 autoshow season. During my time supporting this activation between July 2021 and March 2022, it was brought to 8 different auto shows and 28,552 total videos were sent to customers. The activation is still brought to auto shows across the country today.

title: Driving While Black
subtitle: lorem ipsum
body: The simple act of “Driving While Black” in America can quickly turn into an experience fraught with tension, fear, and the looming threat of violence. Studies consistently reveal that black motorists are more likely to experience aggressive tactics, excessive use of force, and even lethal violence compared to their white counterparts. To bring awareness to this issue, Critical Mass partnered with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners to create an experience that allows users to step into the shoes of Black drivers. Debuted at the Detroit Auto Show 2023, CM and GSP unveiled a concept car to highlight the double standards Black people experience. The goal was to spark conversation and promote change across the country.

sections.videoEmbed: <iframe width='100%' height='100%' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/bOhjdpQ9cEA?si=hY2fLlj-BZCi6V4i' title='YouTube video player' frameborder='0' allow='accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share' referrerpolicy='strict-origin-when-cross-origin' allowfullscreen></iframe>

sections.body: The centerpiece of the experience was an augmented reality activation that allowed users to explore the prototyped vehicle in a 3D space. At the Detroit Auto Show, this created the illusion that this vehicle was on display along with all the other cars physically at the show. Paired with the experience is a video that is presented as a hype reel, narrating through all the vehicle’s stand-out features. But the underlying message is that these “safety features” such as transparent doors to “eliminate reasonable suspicion” and a steering wheel that “keeps hands visible at all times” are the lengths that Black drivers need to go to in order to feel safe driving in America today.

The campaign won a series of awards including two Anthem Awards in DE&I/Awareness, two Andy Awards in Craft and Idea, three Webby Awards, and four Clios including the Grand in Experience/Activation/Guerilla.

title: Canon Photo Booth Experience
subtitle: lorem ipsum
body:
For CES 2020, Canon had plans to create a flashy centralized fashion show lined with cameras as a fun way to demo their offerings. However, they wanted to make the experience more personalized, so we added a digital component to the activation that would allow the participants to save their images to their Canon Passport profile. With this functionality, users were able to revisit the photos after the show, and this also allowed Canon to collect leads from those who visited the stand.

In addition to increasing participant engagement and lead generation, this application also showcased the abilities of Canon's Software Development Kit. In our particular case, we used it to send data between the cameras and nearby tablets, as well as control the cameras from the tablets themselves.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body:
The Photo Booth experience was a collection of applications that facilitated capturing, saving, and printing images. The user would scan their QR code and take pictures using one of Canon’s premium DSLR cameras. The image would then appear on the tablet and give them the option to either save the picture or retake it. Once the user saved the image, it would be sent to their Canon Passport, and they also had the option to print it on one of Canon’s display printers.

To achieve that user experience, we built a backend application that used Canon’s SDK and acted as a bridge between the camera and the frontend tablet. We had a second backend application for the printer service allowing the tablets to send data to be printed. Lastly, the frontend tablet application served as a dashboard for participants, as well as communicating with both backend services previously mentioned.

title: Aptiv Virtual Tool
subtitle: lorem ipsum
body:
As a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, many companies had to switch their strategies from physical, in-person events to online virtual events. Aptiv was no exception. To stand out in the sea of virtual events that took over the industry, we created an augmented reality tool to showcase Aptiv’s complex offerings and bring a surprise-and-delight factor to the regular virtual meeting.

The goal was to mimic a hands-on experience, giving users a 360 degree view of their smart vehicle architecture and allowing them to click on hotspots to zero in on individual parts of the technology. Each hotspots features a 3D model for users to manipulate on their own screen or launch in AR to see them in their own environment.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: The application was built with Angular, using three.js to handle the 3d models, hotspots, and animations, and Google’s for the augmented reality piece. It’s completely responsive to all screen sizes, and detects screen type to properly guide the user on how to launch the AR models.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.body: The first phase of the project was completed in October 2020 and debuted at the all-virtual CES conference in 2021 that reached over 10,000 attendees in total between customer, employees and other stakeholders. We continued to iterate on the tool as clients expanded its use across the company and delivered a similar tool for Motional - the autonomous driving join venture between Aptiv and Hyundai - later that year.

sections.quote: I want to recognize Imagination for […] helping us find innovative solutions for how we can reach our customers, not only from taking a physical product to a digital solution, but also helping bring that technology to life by doing event remotely by applying different types of digital tools to make it engaging.
sections.speaker: Rachelle Valdez Vice President, Marketing and Communications, Americas at Aptiv

title: Ford & Lincoln Mobile Spec Pods
body:
Upon the return of auto shows during the summer of 2021, one of Ford’s goals was to make vehicle information on the stand more accessible and easier to navigate. Normally spec information is put on a tablet in front of the vehicle. However, this limits the interactions visitors have with the app and also allows for only one user at a time. Additionally, Ford found that users were more hesitant to used shared devices after the COVID-19 pandemic as health and safety were on the forefront of everyone's minds.

As a result, product of this, solution for this (?) the new season of auto shows, we built Ford’s new mobile spec pods. Visitors were now able to scan a QR code and interact with the information on their own devices, as well as explore additional information using links within the application.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: The spec pod application was Angular application that used deep linking to handle QR code scans. It was built with mobile as the primary use case, but completely responsive for those who chose to view the site again at home. The app was also made to WCAG AAA standards per Ford's digital standards. The content was managed using an in-house CMS system.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.body: After the launch of the mobile spec pods, Ford continued to expand the application. We re-skinned the site so the same system could be used on Lincoln stands and we also created specialty versions for events like SEMA and CES where special product innovations were highlighted.

title: Nissan EV Center
subtitle: lorem ipsum
body:
In the past few years, automotive companies have seen a huge surge in electric vehicle sales globally. Consumers are increasingly encouraged to buy electric and there has been greater focus on environmental concerns, tech advancements, and government incentives & regulations. Nissan did not hesitate to respond to this trend. To add to their electric vehicle lineup, they announced their latest model, the ARIYA, in 2022.

However, with the release of this latest electric vehicle, it became clear that younger buyers were still hesitant when it came to their electric vehicle offerings. Nissan wanted to help address these concerns by connecting with this generation on their own terms. Critical Mass built an AI-driven, NLP-based chatbot to deliver seamless and engaging conversation to answer the questions around the ARIYA and EVs in general. The experience was meant to take a “people-centric” approach, allowing research to feel more personalized.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: We partnered with Kore.ai to create a chatbot with knowledge centered around the Nissan ARIYA, Nissan EV Technologies, and electric vehicles in general. A majority of the work revolved around training and maintaining the model. We started by defining simple questions and answers, which the platform used as part of its knowledge base. To further define conversation flow, we then built dialog tasks to link specific user intents with bot responses. This gave us the ability to work on conversational elements and build business logic into the flow. Lastly, we developed visual responses so users could see interactive elements and data visualizations rather than simple text-based answers. Once the bot was deployed, we continued to refine the model and optimize the NLP to improve understanding and interaction with the user.

title: Open Saudi, Open Hearts, Open Doors
body:
On September 27, 2019, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia launched their new e-Visa tourism program. This opened up the doors for citizens of over 50 countries to travel to Saudi Arabia for tourist purposes, an opportunity that was previously restricted. As part of the launch, Imagination organized a dazzling multi-sensory event for VIPs, media, and influencers to experience all the beauty, culture, and heritage the country had to offer.

Imagination offices across the world worked together to develop various pieces of the event, both digital and physical. The US office was tasked with making the home website for the event, which served as both an attractor beforehand and a wrap-up afterwards.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: The website was an Angular application that was fully responsive and cross-browser compatible. The website used Storyblok as the CMS for all text and images and Amazon S3 for hosting. We built the site on a particularly tight timeline, with only 3 weeks for development and 1 week for QA. A true race-against-the-clock project!

title: Canon Passport Experience
body:
Canon’s Passport experience was an application used at live shows and events that allowed participants to track their journey and save information as they visited different touchpoints on the stand. Users were taken through a quick registration process then sent a QR code, which they scanned to save visits to their profile, which could later be accessed through their own personalized ‘souvenir site’. Additionally, to help guide participants through the digital experience, emails were sent out once they registered, notified them of specific souvenirs they may have collected, and introduced them to their souvenir site once the show ended.

The application was used for most Canon events from 2019-2020 , most notably the Consumer Electronics Show (2019 and 2020), the Albuquerque Balloon Fiesta (2019), and the National Association of Broadcasters Show (2019).

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: Behind the passport experience is an internal suite of software services created by Imagination. This API framework is the bread and butter of the passport system, allowing businesses to connect every touchpoint across the customer journey, enabling them to measure, analyze, and improve every step using real-time data. All this data feeds into an analytics platform that’s used to visualize key metrics such as visitor numbers, dwell time, content views, and interactions.

title: Nissan High Definition Road Map
body:
With the debut of Nissan's latest iteration of driver-assist technology, ProPilot Assist 2.0, the first question in everyone's minds was where it could be used. With a need to present this information in an engaging, interactive way, the solution was obvious: a map. And not just a regular map - the very map that is used in the ProPilot Assist system with accuracy down to the centimeter.

Partnering with HD Map provider, Dynamic Map Platform (formerly Ushr), we created this map, displaying the data in a fully interactive way. It allows users to zoom in or out points of interest, pan across the country, as well as search specific location with autocomplete powered by Google.
skills: OpenLayers, OpenStreetMap, Jinja, Jenkins, Jira, Gulp

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: The map uses OpenLayers and map tiles to display the map data. The base layer map comes from OpenStreetMap and the marked overlay is served by Dynamic Map Platform. Location lookup and functionality are done using Google's Places and Autocompletion services.

title: Nissan ARIYA Launch Campaign
body: With the long-awaited Nissan ARIYA, rolled out in 2023, Nissan was looking to raise excitement around its new all-electric SUV. For customers coming from their media and social campaigns, they needed a landing page to encourage customers to keep exploring the details of the new vehicle. Drawing from the already existing duality theme of the Ariya, we created a page to demonstrate all that the Ariya could achieve. From "fiercely refined" to "elegantly exhilarating", the site displayed split videos, key metrics, and plenty of images to draw the users into the experience.

sections.title: Technical Details
sections.body: The site was built with Gatbsy.js, interlacing video and animation. It contains a variety of CTAs to encourage users to read more, try out the ARIYA AR app, as well as visit the virtual reality experience. The site meets WCAG accessibility standards, includes site analytics, and incorporates SEO best practices.  I led a team of two developers and one QA analyst to deliver this site in a very tight three month timeline.

title: Infiniti Rebrand
body: In June 2023, Infiniti announced a brand refresh, complete with a new logo, color scheme, showrooms, sounds, and even fragrance. It's digital properties were making the transition from a primarily black & white palette to blue & beige with its signature horizon graphic. Our part in the overhaul was to ensure all Infiniti Shopping Tools pages followed the new brand guideline for both the American and Canadian markets. These pages included its build & price tool, inventory search, and payment estimator. I led a team of 2 developers and 2 QA analysts to complete the project in just under four months.

sections.title: Project Details
sections.body: As a crossover between the delivery team and technology team, I helped support project planning  tasks as well as the development and release phases. I provided estimates for frontend tasks to help inform prioritization, scheduling, and resourcing. From there, we agreed on key milestones for each application to ensure we hit our target date and demo progress to the clients. For the development phase, I led a team of two developers and two QA analysts to complete the project in just under four months. The  process also required coordination with the AEM and content management teams as we worked through dependencies. The initial production release was done on June 22, 2023, with rolling releases afterward for subsequent milestones.

title: QX60 Competitor Compare
body:
After the redesign of the QX60 SUV in 2023, Infiniti wanted to create a site that highlighted all the vehicle's stand-out features and showcased where it excelled against its competitors. In contrast to the rest of the site - mostly made up of static pages - they wanted something interactive and dynamic that customers could use to explore all angles of the QX60.

The biggest challenge in the project brief was load time expectations. The client was planning on making it the landing page of the QX60, a page that was crucial to user journey. The higher the load time, the higher the bounce rate, ending a user’s journey before it even starts. So having the site load in under a few seconds was a non-negotiable.

sections.title: Project Details
sections.body: With loading times in mind, we ruled out WebGL - the standard approach to 3D experiences. We had to find a way to give the users a similar experience without the overhead of big files. So instead we turned to video. We collaborated with motion designers to define the movements of the QX60 model for each page transition. Those segments were combined into a single video, which we used as the primary asset on the site. Using GSAP ScrollTrigger and scroll snap, we scrubbed the video based on scroll progress and overlaid hotspot at each stopping point. The outcome was everything a 3D experience could provide without the incorporation of actual 3D components.
